content:
I find the font size too small here (font-size: 14px, line-height: 17px). How about if we change it to (~15px) with a line-height (~20px). This will make our layout a lot cleaner. Here is the quick mockup (notice the left-sidebar, centre message content and right sidebar)-
pasted image

@Akash Nimare I think we are planning to do something like that, probably under a setting for how dense you want your messages to appear. It's not an easy project to do, since there's a lot of things that might be visually out of whack in such an implementation.

The only big app that does the density thing is the old GMail.
We are way below the average for most of the web apps (I did some research a month ago)
In fact 15px is still on the lower end, but I am in favor of going for 15px, instead of waiting for months/years/never to implement a customization feature that I personally think is an overkill.
Also, line-height is almost always better set in unitless values. As in 1.4 which I think is the lowest 'dense' setting that makes sense.
1.4 means 1.4 x font-size. 99% of the time line-height set in pixels is a newbie mistake, and only 1% of the cases are actually very advanced typography.
For most of the features we need to make better defaults. BTW, the font in the mobile app is exactly font-size: 15px; line-height: 1.4
Yeah, at first, I made those changes in unitless i.e 1.4, Slack also uses line-height: 1.4.
It may just be the case that I am Old Now, but I definitely prefer a base font size of 16px. I think it gives the text more room to breathe.

BTW, the font in the web app is exactly font-size: 15px;

Currently, It's 14px.
I meant the mobile app :D
I am actually with @Eric Eslinger on that. I would argue for larger font thatn 15px, it is more like small wins better than no wins ;)

I don't like that we are adding so many options. Best UI design is just making sure the default behavior is the best possible. Most users and organizations will not change these, so we are doing them a disservice by not setting the best defaults.

Yeah, while I'm okay with some settings (it is certainly _possible_ to do base font size responsive design, it's just a fair bit more work, and there's a lot of hardcoded pixel sizing in the css right now), I'm more interested in seeing a larger default.

I don't know if this is a controversial thing to say, but hey, I'm here. I'm interested in making zulip a better experience, and part of that experience is getting people roped in on first interaction.

and when I first interacted with zulip, I came in comparing it to slack. relative to slack, the default UI is a lot more busy. There's way more text visible, and that text is smaller. IMO, this makes it feel ... more fiddly. Less immediately engaging.
not the end of the world, but just an observation. i obviously didn't bounce off of the interface, but I kind of wonder how many people would.

I agree that the default should probably be a bit bigger.

Personally I almost always choose the "compact" layout/spacing in apps that offer it, if I use them a lot: Gmail, Google Calendar, Slack come to mind. But the same apps always make a more "comfortable"/"roomy" option the default, and I think that usually is an easier experience when first using a given app.
I think a larger default (e.g. 15px) makes a lot of sense, as is probably something that can happen independent of adding density options.

Even a fixed larger size is not trivial, I think -- when I do a Ctrl-+ in my browser as a quick rough test, a bunch of things in the sidebars get subtly misaligned. Like @Eric Eslinger said, there are a lot of hardcoded pixel sizes in the CSS right now.

I'd be OK with a somewhat bigger fixed size, but personally (and I think a lot of power users will feel the same way) I'd then personally be eager for an option to make it denser again. :smile: Hopefully any work we do on a bigger fixed size would also clean up some of the hardcoding so it's also easier to add an option.
Keep in mind that different fonts have different apparent size at the same pixel size. It seems the font we use looks about 10%-15% smaller still than other popular ones.

I think a larger default (e.g. 15px) makes a lot of sense, as is probably something that can happen independent of adding density options.

No, this will not look good. Increasing the font-size only will tighten up the vertical space between the contents. It's the combination of right font-size + line-height which will make the overall layout better.

@Akash Nimare I think we are planning to do something like that, probably under a setting for how dense you want your messages to appear. It's not an easy project to do, since there's a lot of things that might be visually out of whack in such an implementation.

As Boris said it's better to make the default better first. I have been using this style (font-size: 15px, line-height: 1.4) for a while using Stylebot and haven't noticed a major misalignment of any section though we might need to tweaks a bit of styling but still this will be less than the efforts we have put into dark theme.
Facebook, Slack and Skype use 1.4, others vary. There is no popular app that is as dense as Zulip.
Just a quick vote--I'd like bigger fonts. It's not a huge deal for me, since I usually just zoom Zulip to 133%.

To clarify my suggestion: I agree a 15px font would need to be accompanied by an increase in line height.
I just meant that making that change seems like much less work than supporting multiple densities.
I agree we should change the default size. That said, I think changing the font size (and line height) would be a pretty large and difficult project.
It's definitely not a large project IMO. Think the complications of dark mode but on 1/10th the scale.
I have found that CSS changes are the type of effort suited quite well to a GSoC student. Lots of changes, low-to-medium complexity, almost impossible to introduce a critical issue
